awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   What Controls Calving? A Greenland-wide Test of Terminus Change Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Retreat of the leading edge of marine-terminating glaciers is often associated with ice flow acceleration, increases in iceberg calving rates and discharge to the sea, and glacier thinning. The associated ice mass loss is responsible for approximately half the contribution of the Greenland Ice Sheet to sea level rise thus far this century. For the remainder of the century and beyond, gaps in our understanding of iceberg calving and glacier retreat result in large uncertainties in predictions of mass loss and consequent sea level rise. This collaborative project is designed to reveal the factors controlling terminus retreat and iceberg calving in the diverse settings of Greenland's marine terminating glaciers. The project contributes to STEM workforce development by providing support to two early-career scientists from EPSCoR states, undergraduate student participation at both institutions, and for training of a graduate student.  The principal investigators will continue their active outreach, including museum and classroom visits in the rural settings around their universities, presentations to non-technical groups, and media features.

This project will substantially improve our understanding of marine terminating glacier dynamics via the analysis of recently-available observational datasets. Through these data, the project will evaluate the performance of terminus parameterizations used in numerical ice sheet models, known as "calving laws." Application at 49 diverse marine-terminating glaciers around Greenland (nearly a quarter of the ice sheet total) ensures that project results will be representative. Calving laws applied to conditions at and near glacier termini will predict terminus locations. Predictions will be compared to terminus positions observed in satellite and time-lapse images to identify model misfits. This calibration and validation analysis will reveal when and where specific calving laws reliably reproduce terminus positions and calving rates. Furthermore, extensions of this approach will (1) yield insight into the impact of crevasse water storage on iceberg calving, (2) guide the inclusion of submarine melting to improve prediction by calving laws, and (3) quantify the critical timescales over which glacier properties must be characterized for the prediction of calving rates and terminus positions.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to advance the current understanding of the controls on iceberg calving from glaciers and floating ice tongues and ice shelves. Changes in iceberg calving directly influence the mass of the world's glaciers, ice shelves, and ice sheets, with increased iceberg calving driving the retreat of glacier margins from coastal waters. Ice margin retreat can in turn influence the flow of the ice, potentially causing additional mass loss. Therefore, it is essential that we understand the processes that control iceberg calving and that we accurately model the temporal evolution of glacier margins in response to changes in calving triggered by global climate change.

The project resulted in the development of a number of novel methodologies, surprising results, and helpful guidance for future numerical modeling of glaciers and ice sheets. We used a variety of satellite and airborne remote sensing observations to test the methods that are commonly used to simulate changes in terminus position in numerical ice flow models. Our analysis suggested that the most accurate method is that one that models calving when and where the depth of surface fractures in glacial ice (known as crevasses) penetrate to the ocean surface level. However, as part of this project we also developed a semi-automated approach to map crevasses using airborne lidar observations and found that crevasse depth estimates incorporated in models do not match observations. These results suggest that we need to rethink how account for the role of crebassing in models of iceberg calving in order to accurately model changes in iceberg calving over time. 

We have also worked with state-of-the-art satellite datasets to create time series of iceberg size distributions distributed around the margins of the Greenland Ice Sheet. The size distributions have been created for the densely-packed icebergs and sea ice adjacent to the ice sheet's margins, where other satellite remote sensing approaches struggle to categorize icebergs. These data are being used to explore controls on iceberg calving using a mathematical approach that will potentially shed light on the controls of iceberg calving, ultimately leading to improved models of calving and changes in the position of the ice margin over time.

The project has largely funded personnel from under-represented groups in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) and has provided novel research opportunities for two undergraduate students at a large public university. The undergraduate students have developed scientific research, computer programming, data management and visualization, science communication, and research collaboration skills far beyond what they would have learned through classroom instruction alone. The project lead has also developed collaborative relationships with colleagues across the country and the world throughout this project, allowing her to develop an internationally-recognized research program that is committed to broadening participation in STEM and strengthening the US STEM workforce.
